title-group.article-title: Aero-thermoelastic stability and nonlinear flutter analysis of functionally graded panels

article-meta.aff: 1School of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Seoul National University, Seoul, South Korea
2Institute of Advanced Aerospace Technology, School of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Seoul National University, Seoul, South Korea

author-notes.corresp: Ji-Hwan Kim, 599, Kwanak-ro, Kwanak-ku, Seoul, 151-744, South Korea. Email: jwhkim@snu.ac.kr

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Nonlinear flutter characteristics under the thermal load as well as aerodynamic heating on functionally graded material panels are investigated in the hypersonic flow. Mathematical models are defined such as power-law, sigmoid and exponential functionally graded materials by the volume fractions of the constituents. Further, third-order piston theory of aerodynamics and von Karman strain-displacement relationship is adopted in order to perform the aero-thermoelastic analysis. Applying the principle of virtual work, equations of motion are derived in the matrix form, and then finite element method is used to obtain the discretized equations. Then, the time domains analysis is performed using Newmark’s time integration method. To check the validity of the present formulation, numerical results are compared with the previous data in the literatures.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Problems of the structural vibration characteristics and flutter of a panel have raised a special interest in aerospace and mechanical engineering. Especially, reentry of the space vehicle into the atmosphere experiences high temperature environments. Thus, aero-thermoelastic performances have been studied widely such as thermally induced self-excited oscillations.

For dynamic response of structures, numerous research works have been performed under aerodynamic loads, since panel flutter is a typical phenomenon of the instability in the transonic, supersonic or hypersonic flight ranges. Carnahan and Richards1 studied a modification of filtered-X LMS control of an airfoil vibration and flutter suppression. Raja et al.2 applied for flutter control of a composite plate with piezoelectric multilayered actuators. Kouchakzadeh et al.3 analyzed panel flutter behaviors of general laminated composite plates. Sohn and Kim4 performed nonlinear thermal flutter analysis of a functionally graded panel under a supersonic flow. Prakash and Ganapathi5 investigated the influence of thermal environment on the supersonic flutter behavior of functionally graded panels. Cheng and Mei6 used full third-order piston theory to consider the aerodynamic nonlinearity and verified that the theory is more adequate for the hypersonic range than the supersonic flow model. Song and Li7 investigated the active aeroelastic flutter and vibration control of composite laminated plates with the piezoelectric patches. Besides, Li8 studied on flutter suppression of supersonic plates by using piezoelectric components.

Currently, newly developed advanced materials are being used and have drawn much attention in various engineering fields. One of these is the conventional composites, but the model contains discrete and piecewise characteristics in the interfaces of the layers. To overcome these problems of the structure, a new type of material has been proposed, so-called functionally graded material (FGM).9 In general, the continuous change in the microstructure of FGM is distinct from the fiber-reinforced laminated composite materials. First of all, Kapuria et al.10 fabricated layered FG beam using powder metallurgy and thermal spraying techniques and validated static and free vibration response using experimental results. Up to now, three types of FGM models have been developed such as exponential FGM (E-FGM),11,12 power-law FGM (P-FGM)13,14 and sigmoid FGM (S-FGM)15. Mollarzi et al.16 analyzed the free vibration of FGM cylinders using meshless method. Also, Lee and Kim17 performed comparative evaluations for nonlinear dynamic response of the models. Furthermore, Lee and Kim18 analyzed thermo-mechanical buckling and post-buckling of the three models. And then unique characteristics are briefly stated.

During these investigations, a few works on differences of characteristics for E-FGM, P-FGM and S-FGM were found. Thus, dynamic analysis of the panels is performed in case of P-, S- and E-FGMs. The models are subjected to thermal and hypersonic aerodynamic loadings simultaneously, and the numerical results are verified by the existing data. Furthermore, the third-order piston theory is adopted, and time domains analysis is performed for Newmark’s time integration method. In order to verify the present formulation, numerical results are compared with the previous data.

sec.title: Functionally graded materials
sec.p:
In here, E-FGM,12 P-FGM13 and S-FGM15 are introduced, and the typical geometry of the models is shown in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Geometry of a functionally graded panel.

sec.title: Materials models
sec.p: The three types of materials are briefly stated as follows.

At first, E-FGM is described by exponential function without defining the volume fraction index k as in Ref. [12]. (1)Peff(z,T)=AeB(z+h/2)whereA=Pm,B=1hln (PcPm ) where Peff is defined as effective material property.

Secondly, distributions of ceramic and metal can be changed according to the volume fraction index k due to a simple power law distribution. The volume fractions of the materials can be expressed as:13 (2)Vc(z)= (zh+12 )k(0≤k<∞) where Vc is denoted volume fraction of ceramic.

In order to reduce the stress concentrations rather than the P-FGM case as in equation (2), S-FGM is proposed to ensure smooth distribution of the stresses as follows:15 (3)Vc1(z)=1-12 (1-2zh )k(0≤z≤h/2),Vc2(z)=12 (1+2zh )k(-h/2≤z≤0) where Vc1 and Vc2 are denoted volume fraction of ceramic.

For three types of materials, the volume fractions for P- and S-FGMs are varied according to Vc+Vm=1, while E-FGM is expressed with a constant value in equation (1). Figure 2 depicts the distributions of the volume fraction Vc for indices k. Figure 2.
Volume fraction distributions of functionally graded materials (FGMs) for various volume fraction indices k.

sec.title: Constitutive equations
sec.p: First-order shear deformation theory is used, and then the in-plane strains and curvatures are based on the von Karman strain-displacement relations.

In general, the constitutive equations for the panel are (4) {{N}{M} }= [ [A ] [B ] [B ] [D ] ] {{ɛ0}{γ} }- {{NΔT}{MΔT} }{Q}= [As ]{γ}. where [A ], [B ], [D ] and [As ] are extensional, bending-extension coupling, bending and transverse shear stiffness matrices, respectively. Additionally, {ɛ0} and {γ} represent in-plane strains and curvatures. Meanwhile, {N},{M},{NΔT},{MΔT} and {Q} are matrices representing the forces, moments, thermal forces, thermal moment and transverse shear force, respectively. Furthermore, ( [A ], [B ], [D ] )=∫-h/2 h/2E(1,z,z2)dz and ({NΔT},{MΔT} )=∫-h/2 h/2(1,z)E {α(z),α(z),0 }TΔT(z)dz. In here, E and α(z) denote the elastic coefficient matrix and thermal expansion coefficient. Also, ΔT(z)=T(z)-T0 where T0 and T(z) are the reference temperature and the temperature distribution through the thickness, respectively. Transverse shear stiffness is obtained by As=κp∫-h/2 h/2E(z)2(1+ν) [1001 ]dz where κp represents the shear correction factor.

sec.title: Matrix form of governing equations
sec.p: The principle of virtual work is (5)δW=δWint-δWext=0 where δWint and δWext represent the internal and the external virtual works, respectively.

The internal virtual work is written as (6)∫VδeTσdV=∫A [δɛTN+δκTM+δγTQ ]dA=δdT [K-KΔT+12N1+13N2 ]d -δdTPΔT where d=[u,v,w,ϕx,ϕy]T is the displacement vector. In addition, K, KΔT, N1 and N2 are matrices that denote the linear elastic, thermal geometric, first-order nonlinear and second-order nonlinear stiffness, respectively. Besides, PΔT represents the thermal load vector.

Meanwhile, the external work is expressed as (7)∫A [-I0 (u··0δu0+v··0δv0+w··0δw0 ) - I1 (u··0δφx+φ··xδu0+v··0δφy+φ··yδv0 ) - I2 (φ··xδφx+φ··yδφy )+Pairδw ]dA =-δdTMd··+δdTf where Pair and f are the aerodynamic pressure and the external force vector, respectively. On the other hand, (I0,I1,I2)=∫-h/2 h/2ρ(z)·(1,z,z2)dz.
For the hypersonic range, the third-order piston theory is adopted to calculate the aerodynamic loads as in Ref. [6].

Finally, the governing equations for a FGM panel subjected to aerodynamic and thermal loading can be written as (9)Md··+Add·+ (K-KΔT+λAf+12N1+13N2 )d=PΔT where λ is the non-dimensional aerodynamic pressure given by ρaV∞ 2a3M∞D in here D=Emh312(1-v2). Furthermore, Af is the aerodynamic pressure matrix based on the third-order theory.

The solution of the above equation is assumed as d=ds+dt, where ds and dt represent the time-independent and time-dependent solutions, respectively. Substituting the assumed solution into equation (9), two sets of coupled governing equations are obtained; representing the static and dynamic equations.

Therefore, the dynamic phenomena in the hypersonic flow with the thermal effect are represented. (10)Md··t+gaω0Add·t+ (K-KΔT+λAf+12N1s + 13N2s+N2st+12N1t+13N2t )dt=0 where the subscripts s and t represent the static and dynamic states, respectively.

sec.title: Results and discussions
sec.p: The finite element method is applied to analyze three types of models such as E-FGM, P-FGM and S-FGM. Furthermore, a square panel with 6 × 6 mesh using nine-node elements is used in the numerical analysis. The materials chosen are silicon nitride and stainless steel (Si3N4/SUS304). Additionally, the reference temperature and thickness ratio are 300 K and 100, respectively. On the other hand, the effect of the Poisson’s ratio is less significant than Young’s modulus for FGM.11 Thus, the moduli of E-, P- and S-FGMs are used in this work. In order to prevent shear locking phenomena of the thin-plate model, a selectively reduced integration (SRI) technique19 is applied. As stated in the previous section, the third-order piston theory is employed for the hypersonic airflow. As in Ref. [20], the non-dimensional parameter μ/M∞ varies between 0.01 and 0.1, with μ=ρaa/ρmh. Moreover, material properties change in the thickness direction of the FGM model, and thus a constant shear correction factor is not appropriate.21 Thus, a shear correction factor for FGM plates is introduced as proposed in Ref. [22]. (11)κp=56-(νmVm+νcVc) where Vm and Vc are the volume fraction of metal and ceramic, and νm and νc are Poisson’s ratios, respectively.

Structures are faced with high temperature conditions in hypersonic flow with the material properties dependent on the temperature. Thus, the material properties depend on the temperature as in Ref. [23]. (12)P(T)=P0 (P-1T+1+P1T+P2T2+P3T3 ) where P0, P-1, P1, P2 and P3 are the coefficients as shown in Table 1. Table 1.
Temperature-dependence coefficients for silicon nitride and nickel.23
Properties Materials P−1 P0 P1 P2 P3
E(Pa) Si3N4 0 348.43 × 109 −3.070 × 10−4 2.160 × 10−7 −8.946 × 10−11
SUS304 0 201.04 × 109 3.070 × 10−4 −6.534 × 10−7 0
ρ(Kg/m3) Si3N4 0 2370 0 0 0
SUS304 0 8166 0 0 0
α(1/K) Si3N4 0 5.8723 × 10−6 9.095 × 10−4 0 0
SUS304 0 12.330 × 10−6 8.086 × 10−4 0 0
K(W/mK) Si3N4 0 9.19 0 0 0
SUS304 0 12.04 0 0 0

sec.title: Verifications
sec.p:
Three cases of the FGM models are compared with the previous data. Figure 3 depicts the deflections of S-FGM with the previous work for different ratios of E1/E2 and shows almost equal results as the data in Ref. [24]. Table 2 presents the critical pressures of the panel for various volume fractions in the flutter condition, and then, the present results show a good agreement with the previous data in Ref. [5]. Finally, Figure 4 shows thermal buckling analysis is performed with various aspect ratios, and the results are almost similar to the previous works in Ref. [13]. Figure 3.
The deflection of the sigmoid functionally graded material (S-FGM) panel for different E1/E2.
Figure 4.
Critical temperatures for buckling of P-FGM with the aspect ratio a/b.
Table 2.
Flutter boundaries of temperature dependent functionally graded material (FGM) panels (SI3N4/SUS304, Tm=Tc=300K, a/h = 20)
Volume fraction (k) Prakash et al.5 Present
|ω*cr 2 | λcr |ω*cr 2 | λcr
0 9661.35 775.78 9663.2 776.1
0.5 4575.07 666.01 4577.3 667.2
1 3515.57 625.78 3518.6 628.2
5 2348.72 571.48 2350.6 574.1

sec.title: Nonlinear dynamic responses in the hypersonic flow
sec.p:
In this part, nonlinear behaviors of FGMs are examined due to the effects of hypersonic flow. To perform the analysis, third-order piston theory is used, and the Mach number is chosen to be M∞=10. The stability boundaries of clamped square FGM panel under thermal and aerodynamic loads are presented in Figure 5. Generally, there are four types of panel behaviors: (A) flat and stable, (B) statically buckled but dynamically stable, (C) flutter and (D) chaos. At region (A), the panels remain flat and statically as well as dynamically stable. On the other hand, as increasing the temperature, the panels are buckled but dynamically stable at region (B). Furthermore, the dynamic pressure increases, limit cycle oscillations as shown in region (C) and chaotic motions can be observed in region (D). Figure 5.
Stability boundaries for functionally graded material (FGM) panels (a/h=100). (a) exponential FGM (E-FGM); (b) power-law FGM (P-FGM); (c) sigmoid FGM (S-FGM).

For a more detailed discussion, regions (A) and (C) are investigated in this section. Figure 5(a) shows the E-FGM case, and stands for only one stability boundary. This means that the results are independent of the volume fraction index k. Figure 5(b) deals with the P-FGM case, as the volume fraction index increases, critical aerodynamic pressures for panel flutter and critical temperature for thermal buckling decrease all together. However, Figure 5(c) depicts S-FGM case, and the stability boundaries are almost similar as the variation of volume fraction indices. Up to now, Figure 5(a–c) is explained separately, but additional discussions are presented as follows. For a large index value in P-FGM, the amount of metal is richer than ceramic. While S-FGM case describes the fraction of the materials forms an equal amount as shown in Figure 2(c). Additionally, E-FGM shows almost similar patterns to P-FGM in case of k = 1.

Figure 6 shows FGM panels converge to zero in a stable region for λ=200 andΔT=10K. And the oscillating motions of the models are analyzed using a time step of 0.1 ms. Especially, Figure 6(a) represents a single curve regardless of volume fraction index due to the characteristics of E-FGM. The case shows similar results as the P-FGM for k = 1. While Figures 6(b) and (c) depict the amplitudes are increased as increasing of the volume fraction index k for P- and S-FGMs cases, respectively. Furthermore, the motions converge to stable point quickly as the index is decreased. It is due to the fact that the models are more flexible with the large index, and thus more time is necessary to converge to stable point. Figure 6.
Time responses of functionally graded material (FGM) panels with various volume fraction indices in the stable region (λ=200, ΔT=10K). (a) exponential FGM (E-FGM); (b) power-law FGM (P-FGM); (c) sigmoid FGM (S-FGM).

Figure 7 presents the behaviors of the models exhibit limit-cycle oscillations (LCO) for λ=1500,ΔT=50K and μ/M∞ = 0.1 in the flutter region. In the transient state, the amplitude of oscillations is higher than that of the LCO. Figure 7(a) also shows a single curve regardless of volume fraction index. The E-FGM case has similar behaviors to the P-FGM for k = 1. In P-FGM case, as the index is increased, the amplitude is also increased and the frequency is decreased, Figure 7(b). Due to the increase of the volume fraction of the ceramic, the panel becomes stiffer and reduces the thermal conductivity. While, in S-FGM case, the index is increased, then the frequency is decreased, but the amplitudes are similar in Figure 7(c). It is due to the difference of the characteristics of P- with S-FGMs. For P-FGM case, a large value of the index means the volume fraction of the ceramic is richer than that of the metal. However, variation of the volume fraction index does not affect the fraction of the ceramic and metal in S-FGM model. In other words, the variation of the index does not change the distribution of ceramic and metal. Then, there are not large gaps with the variation of the index. Figure 7.
Limit-cycle oscillations of functionally graded material (FGM) panels with various volume fraction indices in the flutter region (λ=1500, ΔT=50K). (a) exponential FGM (E-FGM); (b) power-law FGM (P-FGM); (c) sigmoid FGM (S-FGM).

As a result, P-FGM characteristics can be easily changed by varying the index k while S-FGM reduces the stress concentrations, but the properties are changed in small amounts by the index k. Additionally, the behaviors of E-FGM are similar motions of P-FGM for k = 1.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this paper, E-FGM, P-FGM and S-FGM are investigated under thermal and hypersonic flow. And the results are compared with previous data of nonlinear dynamic motions of the structures. Aero-thermoelastic stability boundaries and LCOs of the panel are analyzed using the Newmark’s method in a time domain. Then, the present analysis shows that the characteristics of the P-FGM are different from the results of the S- and E-FGMs. For P-FGM, the limit-cycle amplitude increases, but the frequency decreases in the flutter region for the increased volume fraction index. However, in S-FGM case, the frequency is also decreased but the amplitudes of the oscillations are similar as increasing the index. As the index is increased, the amplitude reduction appear later in the stable region for P- and S-FGM. On the other hand, E-FGM has a constant value for the distribution of material properties irrespective of the volume fractions. Besides, the motion of E-FGM is similar to P-FGM with a volume fraction index of k = 1. In here, stability-diagrams in the stable and LCO regions for different temperatures and aerodynamic loads are observed. The remaining issues such as postbuckling behaviors and chaotic motions will be studied in the near future.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: This work was financially supported by the Brain Korea 21 project and College of Engineering at Seoul National University.
